4.passage:
Something must be done for them whenever they leave Norland and settle in a new home."

"Well, then, _let_ something be done for them; but _that_ something need not be three thousand pounds. Consider," [MASK] added, "that when the money is once parted with, it never can return. Your sisters will marry, and it will be gone for ever.

11.passage:
But you have such a generous spirit!"

"I would not wish to do any thing mean," [MASK] replied. "One had rather, on such occasions, do too much than too little.

13.passage:
No one, at least, can think I have not done enough for them: even themselves, they can hardly expect more."

"There is no knowing what _they_ may expect," said [MASK], "but we are not to think of their expectations: the question is, what you can afford to do."

"Certainly

22.passage:
It has given me such an abhorrence of annuities, that I am sure I would not pin myself down to the payment of one for all the world."

"It is certainly an unpleasant thing," replied [MASK], "to have those kind of yearly drains on one s income. One s fortune, as your mother justly says, is _not_ one s own.

27.passage:
They will be much more able to give _you_ something."

"Upon my word," said [MASK], "I believe you are perfectly right. My father certainly could mean nothing more by his request to me than what you say.

29.passage:
Some little present of furniture too may be acceptable then."

"Certainly," returned [MASK]. "But, however, _one_ thing must be considered.

69.passage: She had great satisfaction in replying that she was going into Devonshire. [MASK] turned hastily towards her, on hearing this, and, in a voice of surprise and concern, which required no explanation to her, repeated, "Devonshire! Are you, indeed, going there? So far from hence! And to what part of it?" She explained the situation.

94.passage:
What else can detain him at Norland?"

"Had you any idea of his coming so soon?" said [MASK]. "_I_ had none.

103.passage:
That is good news however; I will ride over tomorrow, and ask him to dinner on Thursday."

"You know him then," said [MASK].

"Know him!

107.passage:
As good a kind of fellow as ever lived, I assure you. A very decent shot, and there is not a bolder rider in England."

"And is _that_ all you can say for him?" cried [MASK], indignantly. "But what are his manners on more intimate acquaintance?

146.passage:
He _would_ have told me so, I doubt not, had I made any such inquiries, but they happened to be points on which I had been previously informed."

"Perhaps," said [MASK], "his observations may have extended to the existence of nabobs, gold mohrs, and palanquins."

"I may venture to say that _his_ observations have stretched much further than _your_ candour.

165.passage:
Her systems have all the unfortunate tendency of setting propriety at nought; and a better acquaintance with the world is what I look forward to as her greatest possible advantage."

After a short pause [MASK] resumed the conversation by saying, 

"Does your sister make no distinction in her objections against a second attachment? or is it equally criminal in every body? Are those who have been disappointed in their first choice, whether from the inconstancy of its object, or the perverseness of circumstances, to be equally indifferent during the rest of their lives?"

"Upon my word, I am not acquainted with the minutiae of her principles.

167.passage:
I only know that I never yet heard her admit any instance of a second attachment s being pardonable."

"This," said [MASK], "cannot hold; but a change, a total change of sentiments No, no, do not desire it; for when the romantic refinements of a young mind are obliged to give way, how frequently are they succeeded by such opinions as are but too common, and too dangerous!

169.passage:
Without considering that it was not in her mother s plan to keep any horse, that if she were to alter her resolution in favour of this gift, she must buy another for the servant, and keep a servant to ride it, and after all, build a stable to receive them, she had accepted the present without hesitation, and told her sister of it in raptures.

"He intends to send his groom into Somersetshire immediately for it," [MASK] added, "and when it arrives we will ride every day. You shall share its use with me.

206.passage:
And I hope she is well."

"Whom do you mean, ma am?" said [MASK], colouring a little.

"Oh!

212.passage:
What can you have to do in town at this time of year?"

"My own loss is great," [MASK] continued, "in being obliged to leave so agreeable a party; but I am the more concerned, as I fear my presence is necessary to gain your admittance at Whitwell."

What a blow upon them all was this!

216.passage:
He shook his head.

"We must go," said [MASK]. "It shall not be put off when we are so near it.

246.passage:
The complaints and lamentations which politeness had hitherto restrained, now burst forth universally; and they all agreed again and again how provoking it was to be so disappointed.

"I can guess what his business is, however," said [MASK] exultingly.

"Can you, ma am?" said almost every body.

268.passage:
She wondered, with little intermission what could be the reason of it; was sure there must be some bad news, and thought over every kind of distress that could have befallen him, with a fixed determination that he should not escape them all.

"Something very melancholy must be the matter, I am sure," said [MASK]. "I could see it in his face.

277.passage:
But are you really so attached to this place as to see no defect in it?"

"I am," said [MASK]. "To me it is faultless.

279.passage:
Nay, more, I consider it as the only form of building in which happiness is attainable, and were I rich enough I would instantly pull Combe down, and build it up again in the exact plan of this cottage."

"With dark narrow stairs and a kitchen that smokes, I suppose," said [MASK].

"Yes," cried he in the same eager tone, "with all and every thing belonging to it; in no one convenience or inconvenience about it, should the least variation be perceptible.

346.passage:
The person is not tall enough for him, and has not his air."

"He has, he has," cried [MASK], "I am sure he has. His air, his coat, his horse.

356.passage:
They are seen only as a nuisance, swept hastily off, and driven as much as possible from the sight."

"It is not every one," said [MASK], "who has your passion for dead leaves."

"No; my feelings are not often shared, not often understood.

366.passage:
Because," replied he, smiling, "among the rest of the objects before me, I see a very dirty lane."

"How strange!" said [MASK] to herself as she walked on.

"Have you an agreeable neighbourhood here?

387.passage:
Beyond a competence, it can afford no real satisfaction, as far as mere self is concerned."

"Perhaps," said [MASK], smiling, "we may come to the same point. _Your_ competence and _my_ wealth are very much alike, I dare say; and without them, as the world goes now, we shall both agree that every kind of external comfort must be wanting.

391.passage:
I guessed how it would end."

"And yet two thousand a-year is a very moderate income," said [MASK]. "A family cannot well be maintained on a smaller.

442.passage:
Yes, very."

"I do not understand you," replied [MASK], colouring. "Reserved!

452.passage:
He is fastidious and will have an affectation of his own."

"It is very true," said [MASK], "that admiration of landscape scenery is become a mere jargon. Every body pretends to feel and tries to describe with the taste and elegance of him who first defined what picturesque beauty was.

454.passage:
I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and meaning."

"I am convinced," said [MASK], "that you really feel all the delight in a fine prospect which you profess to feel. But, in return, your sister must allow me to feel no more than I profess.

479.passage:
But (with a smile) you would be materially benefited in one particular at least you would know where to go when you left them."

"I do assure you," [MASK] replied, "that I have long thought on this point, as you think now. It has been, and is, and probably will always be a heavy misfortune to me, that I have had no necessary business to engage me, no profession to give me employment, or afford me any thing like independence.

509.passage:
The rent of this cottage is said to be low; but we have it on very hard terms, if we are to dine at the park whenever any one is staying either with them, or with us."

"They mean no less to be civil and kind to us now," said [MASK], "by these frequent invitations, than by those which we received from them a few weeks ago. The alteration is not in them, if their parties are grown tedious and dull.

513.passage:
They were obliged to put an end to such an expectation.

"Not go to town!" cried [MASK], with a laugh, "I shall be quite disappointed if you do not. I could get the nicest house in the world for you, next door to ours, in Hanover-square.

517.passage:
Her love made no answer; and after slightly bowing to the ladies, began complaining of the weather.

"How horrid all this is!" said [MASK]. "Such weather makes every thing and every body disgusting.

554.passage:
He cannot bear writing, you know," she continued "he says it is quite shocking."

"No," said [MASK], "I never said any thing so irrational. Don t palm all your abuses of language upon me."

"There now; you see how droll he is.

561.passage:
I am monstrous glad of it, for then I shall have her for a neighbour you know."

"Upon my word," replied [MASK], "you know much more of the matter than I do, if you have any reason to expect such a match."

"Don t pretend to deny it, because you know it is what every body talks of.

583.passage:
It was painful to him even to keep a third cousin to himself.

"Do come now," said [MASK] "pray come you must come I declare you shall come You can t think how you will like them.

669.passage:
But I am determined to set for it the very first opportunity."

"You are quite in the right," replied [MASK] calmly. They then proceeded a few paces in silence.

672.passage:
I shall have no fortune, and I fancy she is an exceeding proud woman."

"I certainly did not seek your confidence," said [MASK]; "but you do me no more than justice in imagining that I may be depended on. Your secret is safe with me; but pardon me if I express some surprise at so unnecessary a communication.

693.passage:
Perhaps you might notice the ring when you saw him?"

"I did," said [MASK], with a composure of voice, under which was concealed an emotion and distress beyond any thing she had ever felt before. She was mortified, shocked, confounded.

710.passage:
I will not apologize therefore for bringing it forward again."

"Thank you," cried [MASK] warmly, "for breaking the ice; you have set my heart at ease by it; for I was somehow or other afraid I had offended you by what I told you that Monday."

"Offended me!

714.passage:
Could you have a motive for the trust, that was not honourable and flattering to me?"

"And yet I do assure you," replied [MASK], her little sharp eyes full of meaning, "there seemed to me to be a coldness and displeasure in your manner that made me quite uncomfortable. I felt sure that you was angry with me; and have been quarrelling with myself ever since, for having took such a liberty as to trouble you with my affairs.

754.passage:
Certainly not."

"I am sorry for that," returned [MASK], while her eyes brightened at the information, "it would have gave me such pleasure to meet you there! But I dare say you will go for all that.

795.passage: Has no letter been left here for me since we went out?" said she to the footman who then entered with the parcels. She was answered in the negative. "Are you quite sure of it?" [MASK] replied.

802.passage:
I always pity them when they do; they seem to take it so much to heart."

"That is true," cried [MASK], in a cheerful voice, and walking to the window as she spoke, to examine the day. "I had not thought of _that_.

804.passage: It was a lucky recollection, all her good spirits were restored by it. "It is charming weather for _them_ indeed," [MASK] continued, as she sat down to the breakfast table with a happy countenance. "How much they must enjoy it!

844.passage:
At that moment she first perceived him, and her whole countenance glowing with sudden delight, she would have moved towards him instantly, had not her sister caught hold of her.

"Good heavens!" [MASK] exclaimed, "he is there he is there

850.passage:
My card was not lost, I hope."

"But have you not received my notes?" cried [MASK] in the wildest anxiety. "Here is some mistake I am sure some dreadful mistake.

870.passage:
Think of your mother; think of her misery while _you_ suffer: for her sake you must exert yourself."

"I cannot, I cannot," cried [MASK]; "leave me, leave me, if I distress you; leave me, hate me, forget me! but do not torture me so.

881.passage:
Every additional day of unhappy confidence, on your side, would have made the blow more dreadful."

"Engagement!" cried [MASK], "there has been no engagement."

"No engagement!"

"No, he is not so unworthy as you believe him.

898.passage:
It is a reasonable and laudable pride which resists such malevolence."

"No, no," cried [MASK], "misery such as mine has no pride. I care not who knows that I am wretched.

915.passage:
With a hasty exclamation of Misery, and a sign to her sister not to follow her, she directly got up and hurried out of the room.

"Poor soul!" cried [MASK], as soon as she was gone, "how it grieves me to see her! And I declare if she is not gone away without finishing her wine!

960.passage:
In this manner they had continued about a quarter of an hour, when Marianne, whose nerves could not then bear any sudden noise, was startled by a rap at the door.

"Who can this be?" cried [MASK]. "So early too!

985.passage:
He had left her, promising to return; he neither returned, nor wrote, nor relieved her."

"This is beyond every thing!" exclaimed [MASK].

"His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both.

1007.passage:
and the Doctor is a single man, I warrant you."

"There now," said [MASK], affectedly simpering, "everybody laughs at me so about the Doctor, and I cannot think why. My cousins say they are sure I have made a conquest; but for my part I declare I never think about him from one hour s end to another.

1124.passage:
He bestowed his hearty approbation however on their species of house.

"For my own part," said [MASK], "I am excessively fond of a cottage; there is always so much comfort, so much elegance about them. And I protest, if I had any money to spare, I should buy a little land and build one myself, within a short distance of London, where I might drive myself down at any time, and collect a few friends about me, and be happy.

1151.passage:
It was not fit that you should then know how much I was the reverse!"

"Four months!" cried [MASK] again. "So calm!

1164.passage:
The next morning brought a farther trial of it, in a visit from their brother, who came with a most serious aspect to talk over the dreadful affair, and bring them news of his wife.

"You have heard, I suppose," said [MASK] with great solemnity, as soon as he was seated, "of the very shocking discovery that took place under our roof yesterday."

They all looked their assent; it seemed too awful a moment for speech.

1189.passage:
I left her this morning with her lawyer, talking over the business."

"Well!" said [MASK], "that is _her_ revenge. Everybody has a way of their own.

1209.passage:
No, no; they were shut up in the drawing-room together, and all I heard was only by listening at the door."

"How!" cried [MASK]; "have you been repeating to me what you only learnt yourself by listening at the door? I am sorry I did not know it before; for I certainly would not have suffered you to give me particulars of a conversation which you ought not to have known yourself.

1223.passage:
No, I cannot go to Cleveland."

"You forget," said [MASK] gently, "that its situation is not that it is not in the neighbourhood of "

"But it is in Somersetshire.

1246.passage:
Well, my dear, I wish you joy of it again and again; and if ever there was a happy couple in the world, I think I shall soon know where to look for them."

"You mean to go to Delaford after them I suppose," said [MASK], with a faint smile.

"Aye, my dear, that I do, indeed.

1272.passage:
The unkindness of your own relations has made you astonished to find friendship any where."

"No," replied [MASK], with sudden consciousness, "not to find it in _you;_ for I cannot be ignorant that to you, to your goodness, I owe it all. I feel it I would express it if I could but, as you well know, I am no orator."

"You are very much mistaken.

1343.passage:
He took the opposite chair, and for half a minute not a word was said by either.

"Pray be quick, sir," said [MASK], impatiently; "I have no time to spare."

He was sitting in an attitude of deep meditation, and seemed not to hear her.

1345.passage:
He was sitting in an attitude of deep meditation, and seemed not to hear her.

"Your sister," said [MASK], with abruptness, a moment afterwards "is out of danger. I heard it from the servant.

1370.passage:
To avoid a comparative poverty, which her affection and her society would have deprived of all its horrors, I have, by raising myself to affluence, lost every thing that could make it a blessing."

"You did then," said [MASK], a little softened, "believe yourself at one time attached to her?"

"To have resisted such attractions, to have withstood such tenderness!

1377.passage:
And how you will explain away any part of your guilt in that dreadful business, I confess is beyond my comprehension."

"Remember," cried [MASK], "from whom you received the account. Could it be an impartial one?

1387.passage:
[MASK] first spoke.

"Did you tell her that you should soon return?"

"I do not know what I told her," he replied, impatiently; "less than was due to the past, beyond a doubt, and in all likelihood much more than was justified by the future.

1388.passage:
Did you tell her that you should soon return?"

"I do not know what I told her," [MASK] replied, impatiently; "less than was due to the past, beyond a doubt, and in all likelihood much more than was justified by the future. I cannot think of it.

1390.passage:
He stopped.

"Well, sir," said [MASK], who, though pitying him, grew impatient for his departure, "and this is all?"

"All!

1420.passage:
His answer was not very encouraging.

"As to that," said [MASK], "I must rub through the world as well as I can. Domestic happiness is out of the question.

1480.passage:
_My_ happiness never was his object."

"At present," continued [MASK], "he regrets what he has done. And why does he regret it?

1509.passage:
[MASK] replied, with an air of surprise. "No, my mother is in town."

"I meant

1523.passage:
and I believe I may say that since the first half year of our foolish business this is the only letter I ever received from her, of which the substance made me any amends for the defect of the style."

"However it may have come about," said [MASK], after a pause, "they are certainly married. And your mother has brought on herself a most appropriate punishment.

1526.passage:
Nothing but such a persuasion could have prevented his putting an end to an engagement, which, long before the discovery of it laid him open to his mother s anger, had been a continual source of disquiet and regret to him.

"I thought it my duty," said [MASK], "independent of my feelings, to give her the option of continuing the engagement or not, when I was renounced by my mother, and stood to all appearance without a friend in the world to assist me. In such a situation as that, where there seemed nothing to tempt the avarice or the vanity of any living creature, how could I suppose, when she so earnestly, so warmly insisted on sharing my fate, whatever it might be, that any thing but the most disinterested affection was her inducement?

1536.passage:
I know of no submission that _is_ proper for me to make."

"You may certainly ask to be forgiven," said [MASK], "because you have offended; and I should think you might _now_ venture so far as to profess some concern for having ever formed the engagement which drew on you your mother s anger."

He agreed that he might.
